elements.content: A new porous metal–organic framework (TMU-21) that is isostructural to our recently reported TMU-6 is introduced. The structure of this framework has been determined by X-ray crystallography and further characterized by Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy, elemental analysis, and thermogravimetric analysis. Its structural features as well as its stability and porosity were studied. These two metal–organic frameworks are interesting candidates for a comparative fluorescence study. Thus, their potential abilities to sense nitrobenzene, benzene, and polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons, namely, naphthalene, anthracene, and pyrene, were investigated. This study clearly shows an important contribution of extending the π-electron systems of pillaring linkers in the ability of metal–organic frameworks to sense aromatic compounds.
elements.clean_text: A new porous metal-organic framework (TMU-21) that is isostructural to our recently reported TMU-6 is introduced. The structure of this framework has been determined by X-ray crystallography and further characterized by Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy, elemental analysis, and thermogravimetric analysis. Its structural features as well as its stability and porosity were studied. These two metal-organic frameworks are interesting candidates for a comparative fluorescence study. Thus, their potential abilities to sense nitrobenzene, benzene, and polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons, namely, naphthalene, anthracene, and pyrene, were investigated. This study clearly shows an important contribution of extending the π-electron systems of pillaring linkers in the ability of metal-organic frameworks to sense aromatic compounds.

elements.content: A new porous metal−organic framework (TMU-21) that is isostructural to our recently reported TMU-6 is introduced. These two metal−organic frameworks are interesting candidates for a comparative fluorescence study. Thus, their potential abilities to sense nitrobenzene, benzene, and polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons, namely, naphthalene, anthracene, and pyrene, were investigated.
elements.clean_text: A new porous metal-organic framework (TMU-21) that is isostructural to our recently reported TMU-6 is introduced. These two metal-organic frameworks are interesting candidates for a comparative fluorescence study. Thus, their potential abilities to sense nitrobenzene, benzene, and polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons, namely, naphthalene, anthracene, and pyrene, were investigated.

elements.content: In the past decade, metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) have attracted considerable interest because of their potential applications in different fields such as catalysis, gas storage, and sensing. This interest is largely based on the ability to tailor the topology, pore size, and functionality by judicious selection of the molecular building blocks. Taking advantage of this feature, many chemists have tried to design various MOFs with desirable structures and properties. The selective molecular recognition and sensing of small molecules by MOFs have been identified as one of the important and exciting areas of research in recent years. Much attention has been focused on sensing and removal of toxic chemicals, such as nitroaromatic compounds (NACs), small aromatics, and polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons (PAHs). Recently, it has been proposed that the aromatic organic ligands in the MOF structure play an important role in interacting with organic analytes via π-interactions, namely, π–π stacking and C–H···π interactions.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

In the past decade, metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) have attracted considerable interest because of their potential applications in different fields such as catalysis, gas storage, and sensing. This interest is largely based on the ability to tailor the topology, pore size, and functionality by judicious selection of the molecular building blocks. Taking advantage of this feature, many chemists have tried to design various MOFs with desirable structures and properties. The selective molecular recognition and sensing of small molecules by MOFs have been identified as one of the important and exciting areas of research in recent years. Much attention has been focused on sensing and removal of toxic chemicals, such as nitroaromatic compounds (NACs), small aromatics, and polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons (PAHs). Recently, it has been proposed that the aromatic organic ligands in the MOF structure play an important role in interacting with organic analytes via π-interactions, namely, π-π stacking and C-H⋅⋅⋅π interactions.

elements.content: Among a mass of MOFs synthesized to date, isoreticular metal–organic frameworks (IRMOFs) have provided a suitable platform for understanding the structure–function relationship. Because of their structural similarity, one can systematically study the effects of minimal structural variations in the organic linker skeleton or secondary building units (SBUs) of MOFs. On the basis of this strategy, herein, we introduce a new metal–organic framework, TMU-21, which is isostructural to a reported TMU-6 that has been reported recently by some of us. The study reveals the importance of extending the π-electron systems of pillaring linkers in the ability of MOFs to sense aromatic compounds (a).
elements.clean_text: Among a mass of MOFs synthesized to date, isoreticular metal-organic frameworks (IRMOFs) have provided a suitable platform for understanding the structure-function relationship. Because of their structural similarity, one can systematically study the effects of minimal structural variations in the organic linker skeleton or secondary building units (SBUs) of MOFs. On the basis of this strategy, herein, we introduce a new metal-organic framework, TMU-21, which is isostructural to a reported TMU-6 that has been reported recently by some of us. The study reveals the importance of extending the π-electron systems of pillaring linkers in the ability of MOFs to sense aromatic compounds (a).

elements.clean_text: 1  Chemical Structure of the Oxygen Donor Ligand (H2OBA) and Pillaring Struts, Namely, L1 and L2 (a), and the Binuclear Secondary Building Unit in TMU-6 and TMU-21 (b)

elements.content:
Ligand L1 and TMU-6 were synthesized according to the procedures described by some of us.

Synthesis of Ligand L2

The L2 ligand, bis-pyridin-4-ylmethylene-naphthalene-1,5-diamine, was synthesized according to the following procedure. To 4-pyridine carboxaldehyde (1.88 mL, 20.0 mmol) in ethanol (50 mL) was added 1,5-diaminonaphthalene (1.58 g, 10.0 mmol) at room temperature. After the addition of dichloromethane (50 mL) and then 2 drops of formic acid, the mixture was stirred at room temperature for 24 h and then filtered. The resulting yellow crystalline solid was washed with ethanol (3 × 5 mL) and hexane (3 × 5 mL) and crystallized from a CH2Cl2/hexane mixture to give ligand L2: 76% yield; mp 242–245 °C; IR (KBr) 3034­(w), 1627(s), 1594(s), 1553(s), 1500­(w), 1406(s), 1319­(w), 1225(s), 980­(w), 704(s), 650­(w) cm–1; MS m/z 336.3 (M+, base peak).
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Synthesis

Ligand L1 and TMU-6 were synthesized according to the procedures described by some of us. 

Synthesis of Ligand L2

The L2 ligand, bis-pyridin-4-ylmethylene-naphthalene-1,5-diamine, was synthesized according to the following procedure. To 4-pyridine carboxaldehyde (1.88 mL, 20.0 mmol) in ethanol (50 mL) was added 1,5-diaminonaphthalene (1.58 g, 10.0 mmol) at room temperature. After the addition of dichloromethane (50 mL) and then 2 drops of formic acid, the mixture was stirred at room temperature for 24 h and then filtered. The resulting yellow crystalline solid was washed with ethanol (3 × 5 mL) and hexane (3 × 5 mL) and crystallized from a CH2Cl2/hexane mixture to give ligand L2: 76% yield; mp 242-245 °C; IR (KBr) 3034(w), 1627(s), 1594(s), 1553(s), 1500(w), 1406(s), 1319(w), 1225(s), 980(w), 704(s), 650(w) cm-1; MS m/z 336.3 (M+, base peak).

elements.content: For this synthesis, 0.298 g of Zn­(NO3)2·6H2O (1 mmol), 0.181 g of synthesized 4-nbpy (0.5 mmol), and 0.258 g of H2oba (1 mmol) were first dissolved in 15 mL of N,N′-dimethylformamide (DMF). The mixture was then placed in a Teflon reactor and heated at 120 °C for 3 days. The mixture was then gradually cooled to room temperature over 48 h. Brown crystals were formed on the walls of the reactor with a synthesis yield of 38%: FT-IR (KBr pellet) selected bands, 654­(m), 763­(m), 876­(m), 1017­(m), 1095­(m), 1157(s), 1238­(vs), 1404­(vs), 1504­(m), 1610­(vs), 1671(s), 3416­(w) cm–1. Anal. Calcd for ZnC29.5H26.5N3.5O6.5 {[Zn­(C14H8O5)­(C11H8N2)]·(C3H7NO)1.5}: C, 59.11; H, 4.46; N, 8.18. Found: C, 58.16; H, 4.28; N, 8.08.
elements.clean_text:
Synthesis of [Zn(oba)(4-nbpy)0.5] n ⋅(DMF)1.5 (TMU-21)

For this synthesis, 0.298 g of Zn(NO3)2⋅6H2O (1 mmol), 0.181 g of synthesized 4-nbpy (0.5 mmol), and 0.258 g of H2oba (1 mmol) were first dissolved in 15 mL of N,N'-dimethylformamide (DMF). The mixture was then placed in a Teflon reactor and heated at 120 °C for 3 days. The mixture was then gradually cooled to room temperature over 48 h. Brown crystals were formed on the walls of the reactor with a synthesis yield of 38%: FT-IR (KBr pellet) selected bands, 654(m), 763(m), 876(m), 1017(m), 1095(m), 1157(s), 1238(vs), 1404(vs), 1504(m), 1610(vs), 1671(s), 3416(w) cm-1. Anal. Calcd for ZnC29.5H26.5N3.5O6.5 {[Zn(C14H8O5)(C11H8N2)]⋅(C3H7NO)1.5}: C, 59.11; H, 4.46; N, 8.18. Found: C, 58.16; H, 4.28; N, 8.08.

elements.content: For the purpose of activation, synthesized crystals (TMU-6 and TMU-21) were then soaked in 5 mL of CH3CN solvent for 5 days, with fresh CH3CN added every 24 h. After 5 days, the CH3CN solution was decanted, and activated crystals were dried at 120 °C under vacuum for at least 24 h (after activation): FT-IR (KBr pellet) 656­(w), 779­(m), 874­(w), 1095­(m), 1158(s), 1238­(vs), 1403­(vs), 1504­(m), 1604­(vs) cm–1. Anal. Calcd for ZnC25H16N2O5 {[Zn­(C14H8O5)­(C11H8N2)]}: C, 61.31; H, 3.29; N, 5.72. Found: C, 60.96; H, 3.24; N, 5.70.
elements.clean_text:
Activation Method

For the purpose of activation, synthesized crystals (TMU-6 and TMU-21) were then soaked in 5 mL of CH3CN solvent for 5 days, with fresh CH3CN added every 24 h. After 5 days, the CH3CN solution was decanted, and activated crystals were dried at 120 °C under vacuum for at least 24 h (after activation): FT-IR (KBr pellet) 656(w), 779(m), 874(w), 1095(m), 1158(s), 1238(vs), 1403(vs), 1504(m), 1604(vs) cm-1. Anal. Calcd for ZnC25H16N2O5 {[Zn(C14H8O5)(C11H8N2)]}: C, 61.31; H, 3.29; N, 5.72. Found: C, 60.96; H, 3.24; N, 5.70.

elements.content: TMU-21 was synthesized by combining Zn­(NO3)2·6H2O, the ditopic H2OBA, and L2 ligands using the solvothermal method at 120 °C for 72 h to give suitable X-ray quality crystals. X-ray crystallography revealed that TMU-6 and TMU-21 are isostructural, crystallizing in the monoclinic C2/c space group. The asymmetric unit of TMU-21 consists of one Zn­(II) ion, an OBA ligand, and half of the L2 ligand. In both TMU-6 and TMU-21, each Zn­(II) in the binuclear secondary building unit (SBU) (b) [Zn···Zn separation of 3.494(1) Å for TMU-6 and 3.509(1) Å for TMU-21] coordinated to four oxygen atoms of carboxylate groups belonging to one chelating and two bridging OBA ligands and one nitrogen atom of ligand L2. The SBU nodes are connected to other secondary building units through the carboxylate groups of OBA ligands to form two-dimensional (2D) sheets. The L2 ligands act as pillars between 2D sheets to form the three-dimensional (3D) framework that can be described as a triply interpenetrated pcu α-Po primitive cubic network. Because of the V-shaped geometry of the OBA ligand [∠C–O–C values of 115.4(3)° for TMU-6 and 117.6(4)° for TMU-21], they bridge the SBUs into a 3D network with honeycomb-like hexagonal channels. Both compounds possess large channels, along the [1 0 1̅] direction, with aperture sizes of 7.5 Å × 6.4 Å and 7.0 Å × 5.5 Å (including van der Waals radii of the atoms) for TMU-6 and TMU-21, respectively (a,d). The calculated void spaces per unit cell for guest-free TMU-6 and TMU-21 frameworks are 34.2% (1852.4 Å3) and 32.9% (1864.1 Å3), respectively. Similar to TMU-6, TMU-21 is also nonporous to N2 at 77 K but is porous to CO2 at 195 K [118.0 cm3/g at STP (5.27 mmol/g); Brunauer–Emmett–Teller (BET) surface area of 490 m2/g] (b,e).
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

TMU-21 was synthesized by combining Zn(NO3)2⋅6H2O, the ditopic H2OBA, and L2 ligands using the solvothermal method at 120 °C for 72 h to give suitable X-ray quality crystals. X-ray crystallography revealed that TMU-6 and TMU-21 are isostructural, crystallizing in the monoclinic C2/c space group. The asymmetric unit of TMU-21 consists of one Zn(II) ion, an OBA ligand, and half of the L2 ligand. In both TMU-6 and TMU-21, each Zn(II) in the binuclear secondary building unit (SBU) (b) [Zn⋅⋅⋅Zn separation of 3.494(1) Å for TMU-6 and 3.509(1) Å for TMU-21] coordinated to four oxygen atoms of carboxylate groups belonging to one chelating and two bridging OBA ligands and one nitrogen atom of ligand L2. The SBU nodes are connected to other secondary building units through the carboxylate groups of OBA ligands to form two-dimensional (2D) sheets. The L2 ligands act as pillars between 2D sheets to form the three-dimensional (3D) framework that can be described as a triply interpenetrated pcu α-Po primitive cubic network. Because of the V-shaped geometry of the OBA ligand [∠C-O-C values of 115.4(3)° for TMU-6 and 117.6(4)° for TMU-21], they bridge the SBUs into a 3D network with honeycomb-like hexagonal channels. Both compounds possess large channels, along the [1 0 1̅] direction, with aperture sizes of 7.5 Å × 6.4 Å and 7.0 Å × 5.5 Å (including van der Waals radii of the atoms) for TMU-6 and TMU-21, respectively (a,d). The calculated void spaces per unit cell for guest-free TMU-6 and TMU-21 frameworks are 34.2% (1852.4 Å3) and 32.9% (1864.1 Å3), respectively. Similar to TMU-6, TMU-21 is also nonporous to N2 at 77 K but is porous to CO2 at 195 K [118.0 cm3/g at STP (5.27 mmol/g); Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) surface area of 490 m2/g] (b,e).

elements.content: Representation of (a) TMU-6 and (d) TMU-21, showing the honeycomb channels along the [1 0 1̅] direction. The benzene and naphthalene cores of linkers L1 and L2 are colored yellow. Connolly surfaces of (b) TMU-6 and (e) TMU-21, along the pore channels, with a probe radius of 1.2 Å, with the three interpenetrating frameworks colored red, blue, and orange. Representation of (c) TMU-6 and (f) TMU-21, showing the arrangement of L1 and L2 pillar ligands inside the honeycomb channel walls of TMU-6 and TMU-21, respectively. The benzene and naphthalene cores of L1 and L2 are shown as space-filling models.
elements.clean_text: 1  Representation of (a) TMU-6 and (d) TMU-21, showing the honeycomb channels along the [1 0 1̅] direction. The benzene and naphthalene cores of linkers L1 and L2 are colored yellow. Connolly surfaces of (b) TMU-6 and (e) TMU-21, along the pore channels, with a probe radius of 1.2 Å, with the three interpenetrating frameworks colored red, blue, and orange. Representation of (c) TMU-6 and (f) TMU-21, showing the arrangement of L1 and L2 pillar ligands inside the honeycomb channel walls of TMU-6 and TMU-21, respectively. The benzene and naphthalene cores of L1 and L2 are shown as space-filling models.

elements.content: Powder X-ray diffraction reveals a slight but significant difference between the simulated patterns and the as-synthesized, solvent-exchanged, and activated materials (Figure S5). This points to TMU-6 and TMU-21 as being flexible or breathing frameworks and helps to explain why both are nonporous to N2 but adsorb CO2 and aromatic guests. Guests that give rise to stronger host–guest interactions because of quadrupole moments like CO2 and aromatic molecules are capable of inflating such flexible frameworks again. Also, N2 sorption is measured at 77 K. In small pores, N2 cannot penetrate at this cryogenic temperature. CO2 and aromatic guest adsorption is taking place at room temperature, at which much more thermal and vibrational flexibility of the framework for the inclusion of even large guest molecules is possible.
elements.clean_text: Powder X-ray diffraction reveals a slight but significant difference between the simulated patterns and the as-synthesized, solvent-exchanged, and activated materials (Figure S5). This points to TMU-6 and TMU-21 as being flexible or breathing frameworks and helps to explain why both are nonporous to N2 but adsorb CO2 and aromatic guests. Guests that give rise to stronger host-guest interactions because of quadrupole moments like CO2 and aromatic molecules are capable of inflating such flexible frameworks again. Also, N2 sorption is measured at 77 K. In small pores, N2 cannot penetrate at this cryogenic temperature. CO2 and aromatic guest adsorption is taking place at room temperature, at which much more thermal and vibrational flexibility of the framework for the inclusion of even large guest molecules is possible.

elements.content: A survey of the Cambridge Structural Database (CSD) reveals that both L1 (reference PEXXEW) and L2 (reference XAPTEO) crystallize in triclinic space group P1̅. Hirshfeld surface analysis was conducted for the study of intermolecular interactions and their relative contribution to the Hirshfeld surface area. The contributions of different intermolecular interactions to the Hirshfeld surface areas are illustrated as a histogram in Figure S2. It is noteworthy that, when the benzene core has been replaced with the naphthalene core, the contribution percentages of C–H···π and π···π interactions increase while that of H···H interactions decreases. As depicted in panels c and f of and Figure S1, the L1 and L2 pillar ligands are arranged inside the honeycomb channel walls of TMU-6 and TMU-21, respectively. In these frameworks, the central benzene (for L1) and naphthalene (for L2) core of pillar ligands is mainly involved in pyC–H···π interactions as hydrogen acceptors with pyridinic hydrogen atoms on different pillar ligands. These intermolecular interactions strengthen the pore walls and therefore prevent channel collapse upon guest removal. Investigation of the intermolecular contacts and crystal packing of these two MOFs via Hirshfeld surface analysis also reveals that the contribution of C–H···π and π···π interactions increases on going from TMU-6 to TMU-21 (Figure S2 and Table S1).
elements.clean_text: A survey of the Cambridge Structural Database (CSD) reveals that both L1 (reference PEXXEW) and L2 (reference XAPTEO) crystallize in triclinic space group P1̅. Hirshfeld surface analysis was conducted for the study of intermolecular interactions and their relative contribution to the Hirshfeld surface area. The contributions of different intermolecular interactions to the Hirshfeld surface areas are illustrated as a histogram in Figure S2. It is noteworthy that, when the benzene core has been replaced with the naphthalene core, the contribution percentages of C-H⋅⋅⋅π and π⋅⋅⋅π interactions increase while that of H⋅⋅⋅H interactions decreases. As depicted in panels c and f of  and Figure S1, the L1 and L2 pillar ligands are arranged inside the honeycomb channel walls of TMU-6 and TMU-21, respectively. In these frameworks, the central benzene (for L1) and naphthalene (for L2) core of pillar ligands is mainly involved in pyC-H⋅⋅⋅π interactions as hydrogen acceptors with pyridinic hydrogen atoms on different pillar ligands. These intermolecular interactions strengthen the pore walls and therefore prevent channel collapse upon guest removal. Investigation of the intermolecular contacts and crystal packing of these two MOFs via Hirshfeld surface analysis also reveals that the contribution of C-H⋅⋅⋅π and π⋅⋅⋅π interactions increases on going from TMU-6 to TMU-21 (Figure S2 and Table S1).

elements.content: Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) indicates that TMU-21 has a thermal stability slightly better than that of TMU-6. In both cases, the TGA data show an initial weight loss (∼1%, after heating from room temperature to 100 °C) that is attributed to the loosely bound water molecule. The other weight loss occurred between 100 and 380 °C (∼14.5%), corresponding to the removal of ∼1.5 DMF guest molecules. The third weight loss was observed starting at 380 and 400 °C for TMU-6 and TMU-21, respectively, corresponding to the decomposition of the frameworks (Figure S3). These data are also confirmed by elemental analysis data. To remove the guest DMF molecules from the frameworks, the as-synthesized TMU-6 and TMU-21 were immersed in acetonitrile for 5 days, filtered, and vacuum-dried at 120 °C for 24 h. The activation of these two frameworks was confirmed by FT-IR spectroscopy, elemental analysis, and powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) analysis (Figures S4 and S5). The water stability of these two frameworks was also examined by soaking activated samples in water for 24 h. The PXRD patterns of water-treated samples confirmed that these two MOFs are stable in water (Figure S5).
elements.clean_text: Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) indicates that TMU-21 has a thermal stability slightly better than that of TMU-6. In both cases, the TGA data show an initial weight loss (~1%, after heating from room temperature to 100 °C) that is attributed to the loosely bound water molecule. The other weight loss occurred between 100 and 380 °C (~14.5%), corresponding to the removal of ~1.5 DMF guest molecules. The third weight loss was observed starting at 380 and 400 °C for TMU-6 and TMU-21, respectively, corresponding to the decomposition of the frameworks (Figure S3). These data are also confirmed by elemental analysis data. To remove the guest DMF molecules from the frameworks, the as-synthesized TMU-6 and TMU-21 were immersed in acetonitrile for 5 days, filtered, and vacuum-dried at 120 °C for 24 h. The activation of these two frameworks was confirmed by FT-IR spectroscopy, elemental analysis, and powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) analysis (Figures S4 and S5). The water stability of these two frameworks was also examined by soaking activated samples in water for 24 h. The PXRD patterns of water-treated samples confirmed that these two MOFs are stable in water (Figure S5).

elements.content: Because the composition of these two MOFs is the same, except for the pillar ligand, these frameworks may be good candidates for a comparative fluorescence study. TMU-6 has two absorption bands at 373 and 474 nm, while TMU-21 shows two absorption bands located at 353 and 466 nm. These MOFs exhibit strong fluorescence at 434 nm upon excitation at 373 and 353 nm for TMU-6 and TMU-21, respectively. The observed enhancement of the fluorescence intensity and the hypsochromic shifts relative to free L1 and L2 (for both L1 and L2, λmax = 528 nm) may be due to the charge-transfer transitions between the ligands and central metal atoms, which is previously described in the case of the [Zn2(OBA)2(bpeb)]·2DMF·H2O framework by Vittal and co-workers. The fluorescence properties of TMU-6 and TMU-21 were preliminarily evaluated by immersing the activated MOFs in three aromatic solvents, i.e., benzene, toluene, and nitrobenzene (a and Figures S6 and S7). Notably, these two MOFs exhibit almost complete fluorescence quenching when they are immersed in nitrobenzene, with a quenching efficiency of >98% for both MOFs. Also, the quenching efficiency follows the order toluene < benzene < nitrobenzene, which is in agreement with the electron-withdrawing ability of the substituent group on the aromatic ring.
elements.clean_text: Because the composition of these two MOFs is the same, except for the pillar ligand, these frameworks may be good candidates for a comparative fluorescence study. TMU-6 has two absorption bands at 373 and 474 nm, while TMU-21 shows two absorption bands located at 353 and 466 nm. These MOFs exhibit strong fluorescence at 434 nm upon excitation at 373 and 353 nm for TMU-6 and TMU-21, respectively. The observed enhancement of the fluorescence intensity and the hypsochromic shifts relative to free L1 and L2 (for both L1 and L2, λmax = 528 nm) may be due to the charge-transfer transitions between the ligands and central metal atoms, which is previously described in the case of the [Zn2(OBA)2(bpeb)]⋅2DMF⋅H2O framework by Vittal and co-workers. The fluorescence properties of TMU-6 and TMU-21 were preliminarily evaluated by immersing the activated MOFs in three aromatic solvents, i.e., benzene, toluene, and nitrobenzene (a and Figures S6 and S7). Notably, these two MOFs exhibit almost complete fluorescence quenching when they are immersed in nitrobenzene, with a quenching efficiency of >98% for both MOFs. Also, the quenching efficiency follows the order toluene < benzene < nitrobenzene, which is in agreement with the electron-withdrawing ability of the substituent group on the aromatic ring.

elements.content: (a) Comparison of fluorescence emission spectra of TMU-6 (blue to navy blue) and TMU-21 (pink to brown) in the presence of different concentrations of nitrobenzene. (b) Comparison of Stern–Volmer (SV) plots in the presence of 1 mg of TMU-6 and TMU-21 at different nitrobenzene concentrations ([Q]) in toluene.
elements.clean_text: 2  (a) Comparison of fluorescence emission spectra of TMU-6 (blue to navy blue) and TMU-21 (pink to brown) in the presence of different concentrations of nitrobenzene. (b) Comparison of Stern-Volmer (SV) plots in the presence of 1 mg of TMU-6 and TMU-21 at different nitrobenzene concentrations ([Q]) in toluene.

elements.content: To understand the fluorescence quenching behaviors of these two MOFs, the frontier molecular orbitals of benzene, toluene, and nitrobenzene were calculated using time-dependent DFT (TD-DFT) calculations (see the computational details). As depicted in Figure S8, the LUMO (−2.441 eV) of nitrobenzene lies at energies lower than those of the LUMOs of benzene (−0.271 eV) and toluene (−0.244 eV). The results suggest that a photoinduced electron-transfer (PET) mechanism may be responsible for fluorescence quenching, because the order of quenching efficiency is identical to the order of the LUMO level energies. To understand the quenching effect of nitrobenzene in detail, the Stern–Volmer (SV) quenching plot is constructed by monitoring the fluorescence intensity of both TMU-6 and TMU-21 in the presence of different concentrations (0.001–0.05 M) of nitrobenzene (a and Figures S9–S11). The plots display a linear response with Stern–Volmer quenching constants (K SV) of 314.2 and 573.9 M–1 for TMU-6 and TMU-21, respectively (b). This implies that the fluorescence quenching in the presence of TMU-21 is faster and more effective than that of TMU-6 (Figure S12). The PET mechanism could be further confirmed by observing the following: (i) linear SV behavior or (ii) no overlap between the absorption band of nitrobenzene and the emission band of these MOFs.
elements.clean_text: To understand the fluorescence quenching behaviors of these two MOFs, the frontier molecular orbitals of benzene, toluene, and nitrobenzene were calculated using time-dependent DFT (TD-DFT) calculations (see the computational details). As depicted in Figure S8, the LUMO (-2.441 eV) of nitrobenzene lies at energies lower than those of the LUMOs of benzene (-0.271 eV) and toluene (-0.244 eV). The results suggest that a photoinduced electron-transfer (PET) mechanism may be responsible for fluorescence quenching, because the order of quenching efficiency is identical to the order of the LUMO level energies. To understand the quenching effect of nitrobenzene in detail, the Stern-Volmer (SV) quenching plot is constructed by monitoring the fluorescence intensity of both TMU-6 and TMU-21 in the presence of different concentrations (0.001-0.05 M) of nitrobenzene (a and Figures S9-S11). The plots display a linear response with Stern-Volmer quenching constants (K SV) of 314.2 and 573.9 M-1 for TMU-6 and TMU-21, respectively (b). This implies that the fluorescence quenching in the presence of TMU-21 is faster and more effective than that of TMU-6 (Figure S12). The PET mechanism could be further confirmed by observing the following: (i) linear SV behavior or (ii) no overlap between the absorption band of nitrobenzene and the emission band of these MOFs.

elements.content: The interactions between the host (MOFs) and the guests (nitrobenzene or benzene) were investigated by performing Monte Carlo simulations using the adsorption locator module in Accelrys Materials Studio. The simulation reveals that the most probable adsorption site for small aromatic guests in these frameworks is near the pyridine moiety of pillar ligands and π–π stacking interactions between the analyte and the aromatic backbone of MOFs that plays an important role in the adsorption process (Figure S13). It is to be noted that the preference of π-stacking over hydrogen bonding in analyte–framework binding is expected because of the lack of a strong hydrogen bond donor in the framework skeleton of TMU-6 and TMU-21. The results show that the strength of π–π stacking interactions between the analytes and MOF gradually increases on going from TMU-6 to TMU-21; as a result, the electron transfer between the electron-rich framework and the electron deficient nitrobenzene is facilitated (Table S2). Also, the replacement of L1 with L2 has another consequence, which is the generation of more hydrophobic pore walls for better interaction with aromatic compounds.
elements.clean_text: The interactions between the host (MOFs) and the guests (nitrobenzene or benzene) were investigated by performing Monte Carlo simulations using the adsorption locator module in Accelrys Materials Studio. The simulation reveals that the most probable adsorption site for small aromatic guests in these frameworks is near the pyridine moiety of pillar ligands and π-π stacking interactions between the analyte and the aromatic backbone of MOFs that plays an important role in the adsorption process (Figure S13). It is to be noted that the preference of π-stacking over hydrogen bonding in analyte-framework binding is expected because of the lack of a strong hydrogen bond donor in the framework skeleton of TMU-6 and TMU-21. The results show that the strength of π-π stacking interactions between the analytes and MOF gradually increases on going from TMU-6 to TMU-21; as a result, the electron transfer between the electron-rich framework and the electron deficient nitrobenzene is facilitated (Table S2). Also, the replacement of L1 with L2 has another consequence, which is the generation of more hydrophobic pore walls for better interaction with aromatic compounds.

elements.content: These results encouraged us to further evaluate the sensing ability of TMU-6 and TMU-21 toward PAHs, namely, naphthalene, anthracene, and pyrene. Thus, fluorescence quenching experiments were conducted using three different concentrations of each PAHs. The results reveal that although in the case of benzene (a and Figures S14–S16) these two MOFs behave almost the same, in the cases of larger aromatics (b–d and Figures S17–S27) the sensing becomes more efficient with increasing π-character of the pillar ligand. It is known explicitly that the sensitivity of TMU-21 toward PAHs is significantly enhanced by extending the π-system, which facilitates the analyte–framework interaction by the formation of π–π stacking and C–H···π interactions. We concluded that PAHs with dimensions of width and length both above 5 Å are too large to enter the pores of TMU-6 and TMU-21, whereas small aromatic guests are capable of entering the pores and interacting with the pore walls. Therefore, the interaction of larger PAHs (i.e., pyrene and, to some extent, anthracene) with the MOF framework may be a combination of surface binding via π-interactions and partial entry into MOF inner pores. These results are also confirmed by theoretical simulation, which suggests that TMU-21 interacts more favorably with PAHs than TMU-6 (Table S2).
elements.clean_text: These results encouraged us to further evaluate the sensing ability of TMU-6 and TMU-21 toward PAHs, namely, naphthalene, anthracene, and pyrene. Thus, fluorescence quenching experiments were conducted using three different concentrations of each PAHs. The results reveal that although in the case of benzene (a and Figures S14-S16) these two MOFs behave almost the same, in the cases of larger aromatics (b-d and Figures S17-S27) the sensing becomes more efficient with increasing π-character of the pillar ligand. It is known explicitly that the sensitivity of TMU-21 toward PAHs is significantly enhanced by extending the π-system, which facilitates the analyte-framework interaction by the formation of π-π stacking and C-H⋅⋅⋅π interactions. We concluded that PAHs with dimensions of width and length both above 5 Å are too large to enter the pores of TMU-6 and TMU-21, whereas small aromatic guests are capable of entering the pores and interacting with the pore walls. Therefore, the interaction of larger PAHs (i.e., pyrene and, to some extent, anthracene) with the MOF framework may be a combination of surface binding via π-interactions and partial entry into MOF inner pores. These results are also confirmed by theoretical simulation, which suggests that TMU-21 interacts more favorably with PAHs than TMU-6 (Table S2).

elements.content: Comparison of fluorescence emission spectra of TMU-6 (blue to navy blue) and TMU-21 (pink to brown) in the presence of different concentrations of (a) benzene, (b) naphthalene, (c) anthracene, and (d) pyrene.
elements.clean_text: 3  Comparison of fluorescence emission spectra of TMU-6 (blue to navy blue) and TMU-21 (pink to brown) in the presence of different concentrations of (a) benzene, (b) naphthalene, (c) anthracene, and (d) pyrene.

elements.content: In summary, we present the structure of TMU-21, which is isostructural to a reported TMU-6. The results of this study show how extending the π-system of pillar ligand affects the pore environment. Compared to TMU-6, TMU-21 provides a more hydrophobic and electron-rich pore environment that can interact favorably with aromatic compounds. This has been reflected in their different potentials for sensing organic aromatic molecules and implies that this series of IRMOFs could be a potential sensor for organic analytes.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusion

In summary, we present the structure of TMU-21, which is isostructural to a reported TMU-6. The results of this study show how extending the π-system of pillar ligand affects the pore environment. Compared to TMU-6, TMU-21 provides a more hydrophobic and electron-rich pore environment that can interact favorably with aromatic compounds. This has been reflected in their different potentials for sensing organic aromatic molecules and implies that this series of IRMOFs could be a potential sensor for organic analytes.

cln_elements.content:
Ligand L1 and TMU-6 were synthesized according to the procedures described by some of us.

Synthesis of Ligand L2

The L2 ligand, bis-pyridin-4-ylmethylene-naphthalene-1,5-diamine, was synthesized according to the following procedure. To 4-pyridine carboxaldehyde (1.88 mL, 20.0 mmol) in ethanol (50 mL) was added 1,5-diaminonaphthalene (1.58 g, 10.0 mmol) at room temperature. After the addition of dichloromethane (50 mL) and then 2 drops of formic acid, the mixture was stirred at room temperature for 24 h and then filtered. The resulting yellow crystalline solid was washed with ethanol (3 × 5 mL) and hexane (3 × 5 mL) and crystallized from a CH2Cl2/hexane mixture to give ligand L2: 76% yield; mp 242–245 °C; IR (KBr) 3034­(w), 1627(s), 1594(s), 1553(s), 1500­(w), 1406(s), 1319­(w), 1225(s), 980­(w), 704(s), 650­(w) cm–1; MS m/z 336.3 (M+, base peak).

Synthesis of [Zn­(oba)­(4-nbpy)<sub>0.5</sub>]<sub> <italic toggle="yes">n</italic> </sub>·(DMF)<sub>1.5</sub> (TMU-21)

For this synthesis, 0.298 g of Zn­(NO3)2·6H2O (1 mmol), 0.181 g of synthesized 4-nbpy (0.5 mmol), and 0.258 g of H2oba (1 mmol) were first dissolved in 15 mL of N,N′-dimethylformamide (DMF). The mixture was then placed in a Teflon reactor and heated at 120 °C for 3 days. The mixture was then gradually cooled to room temperature over 48 h. Brown crystals were formed on the walls of the reactor with a synthesis yield of 38%: FT-IR (KBr pellet) selected bands, 654­(m), 763­(m), 876­(m), 1017­(m), 1095­(m), 1157(s), 1238­(vs), 1404­(vs), 1504­(m), 1610­(vs), 1671(s), 3416­(w) cm–1. Anal. Calcd for ZnC29.5H26.5N3.5O6.5 {[Zn­(C14H8O5)­(C11H8N2)]·(C3H7NO)1.5}: C, 59.11; H, 4.46; N, 8.18. Found: C, 58.16; H, 4.28; N, 8.08.
cln_elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Synthesis

Ligand L1 and TMU-6 were synthesized according to the procedures described by some of us. 

Synthesis of Ligand L2

The L2 ligand, bis-pyridin-4-ylmethylene-naphthalene-1,5-diamine, was synthesized according to the following procedure. To 4-pyridine carboxaldehyde (1.88 mL, 20.0 mmol) in ethanol (50 mL) was added 1,5-diaminonaphthalene (1.58 g, 10.0 mmol) at room temperature. After the addition of dichloromethane (50 mL) and then 2 drops of formic acid, the mixture was stirred at room temperature for 24 h and then filtered. The resulting yellow crystalline solid was washed with ethanol (3 × 5 mL) and hexane (3 × 5 mL) and crystallized from a CH2Cl2/hexane mixture to give ligand L2: 76% yield; mp 242-245 °C; IR (KBr) 3034(w), 1627(s), 1594(s), 1553(s), 1500(w), 1406(s), 1319(w), 1225(s), 980(w), 704(s), 650(w) cm-1; MS m/z 336.3 (M+, base peak).

Synthesis of [Zn(oba)(4-nbpy)0.5] n ⋅(DMF)1.5 (TMU-21)

For this synthesis, 0.298 g of Zn(NO3)2⋅6H2O (1 mmol), 0.181 g of synthesized 4-nbpy (0.5 mmol), and 0.258 g of H2oba (1 mmol) were first dissolved in 15 mL of N,N'-dimethylformamide (DMF). The mixture was then placed in a Teflon reactor and heated at 120 °C for 3 days. The mixture was then gradually cooled to room temperature over 48 h. Brown crystals were formed on the walls of the reactor with a synthesis yield of 38%: FT-IR (KBr pellet) selected bands, 654(m), 763(m), 876(m), 1017(m), 1095(m), 1157(s), 1238(vs), 1404(vs), 1504(m), 1610(vs), 1671(s), 3416(w) cm-1. Anal. Calcd for ZnC29.5H26.5N3.5O6.5 {[Zn(C14H8O5)(C11H8N2)]⋅(C3H7NO)1.5}: C, 59.11; H, 4.46; N, 8.18. Found: C, 58.16; H, 4.28; N, 8.08.

processes.cooling rate: gradually cooled to room temperature over 48 h

cln_elements.content:
TMU-21 was synthesized by combining Zn­(NO3)2·6H2O, the ditopic H2OBA, and L2 ligands using the solvothermal method at 120 °C for 72 h to give suitable X-ray quality crystals. X-ray crystallography revealed that TMU-6 and TMU-21 are isostructural, crystallizing in the monoclinic C2/c space group. The asymmetric unit of TMU-21 consists of one Zn­(II) ion, an OBA ligand, and half of the L2 ligand. In both TMU-6 and TMU-21, each Zn­(II) in the binuclear secondary building unit (SBU) (b) [Zn···Zn separation of 3.494(1) Å for TMU-6 and 3.509(1) Å for TMU-21] coordinated to four oxygen atoms of carboxylate groups belonging to one chelating and two bridging OBA ligands and one nitrogen atom of ligand L2. The SBU nodes are connected to other secondary building units through the carboxylate groups of OBA ligands to form two-dimensional (2D) sheets. The L2 ligands act as pillars between 2D sheets to form the three-dimensional (3D) framework that can be described as a triply interpenetrated pcu α-Po primitive cubic network. Because of the V-shaped geometry of the OBA ligand [∠C–O–C values of 115.4(3)° for TMU-6 and 117.6(4)° for TMU-21], they bridge the SBUs into a 3D network with honeycomb-like hexagonal channels. Both compounds possess large channels, along the [1 0 1̅] direction, with aperture sizes of 7.5 Å × 6.4 Å and 7.0 Å × 5.5 Å (including van der Waals radii of the atoms) for TMU-6 and TMU-21, respectively (a,d). The calculated void spaces per unit cell for guest-free TMU-6 and TMU-21 frameworks are 34.2% (1852.4 Å3) and 32.9% (1864.1 Å3), respectively. Similar to TMU-6, TMU-21 is also nonporous to N2 at 77 K but is porous to CO2 at 195 K [118.0 cm3/g at STP (5.27 mmol/g); Brunauer–Emmett–Teller (BET) surface area of 490 m2/g] (b,e).

Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) indicates that TMU-21 has a thermal stability slightly better than that of TMU-6. In both cases, the TGA data show an initial weight loss (∼1%, after heating from room temperature to 100 °C) that is attributed to the loosely bound water molecule. The other weight loss occurred between 100 and 380 °C (∼14.5%), corresponding to the removal of ∼1.5 DMF guest molecules. The third weight loss was observed starting at 380 and 400 °C for TMU-6 and TMU-21, respectively, corresponding to the decomposition of the frameworks (Figure S3). These data are also confirmed by elemental analysis data. To remove the guest DMF molecules from the frameworks, the as-synthesized TMU-6 and TMU-21 were immersed in acetonitrile for 5 days, filtered, and vacuum-dried at 120 °C for 24 h. The activation of these two frameworks was confirmed by FT-IR spectroscopy, elemental analysis, and powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) analysis (Figures S4 and S5). The water stability of these two frameworks was also examined by soaking activated samples in water for 24 h. The PXRD patterns of water-treated samples confirmed that these two MOFs are stable in water (Figure S5).
cln_elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

TMU-21 was synthesized by combining Zn(NO3)2⋅6H2O, the ditopic H2OBA, and L2 ligands using the solvothermal method at 120 °C for 72 h to give suitable X-ray quality crystals. X-ray crystallography revealed that TMU-6 and TMU-21 are isostructural, crystallizing in the monoclinic C2/c space group. The asymmetric unit of TMU-21 consists of one Zn(II) ion, an OBA ligand, and half of the L2 ligand. In both TMU-6 and TMU-21, each Zn(II) in the binuclear secondary building unit (SBU) (b) [Zn⋅⋅⋅Zn separation of 3.494(1) Å for TMU-6 and 3.509(1) Å for TMU-21] coordinated to four oxygen atoms of carboxylate groups belonging to one chelating and two bridging OBA ligands and one nitrogen atom of ligand L2. The SBU nodes are connected to other secondary building units through the carboxylate groups of OBA ligands to form two-dimensional (2D) sheets. The L2 ligands act as pillars between 2D sheets to form the three-dimensional (3D) framework that can be described as a triply interpenetrated pcu α-Po primitive cubic network. Because of the V-shaped geometry of the OBA ligand [∠C-O-C values of 115.4(3)° for TMU-6 and 117.6(4)° for TMU-21], they bridge the SBUs into a 3D network with honeycomb-like hexagonal channels. Both compounds possess large channels, along the [1 0 1̅] direction, with aperture sizes of 7.5 Å × 6.4 Å and 7.0 Å × 5.5 Å (including van der Waals radii of the atoms) for TMU-6 and TMU-21, respectively (a,d). The calculated void spaces per unit cell for guest-free TMU-6 and TMU-21 frameworks are 34.2% (1852.4 Å3) and 32.9% (1864.1 Å3), respectively. Similar to TMU-6, TMU-21 is also nonporous to N2 at 77 K but is porous to CO2 at 195 K [118.0 cm3/g at STP (5.27 mmol/g); Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) surface area of 490 m2/g] (b,e).

Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) indicates that TMU-21 has a thermal stability slightly better than that of TMU-6. In both cases, the TGA data show an initial weight loss (~1%, after heating from room temperature to 100 °C) that is attributed to the loosely bound water molecule. The other weight loss occurred between 100 and 380 °C (~14.5%), corresponding to the removal of ~1.5 DMF guest molecules. The third weight loss was observed starting at 380 and 400 °C for TMU-6 and TMU-21, respectively, corresponding to the decomposition of the frameworks (Figure S3). These data are also confirmed by elemental analysis data. To remove the guest DMF molecules from the frameworks, the as-synthesized TMU-6 and TMU-21 were immersed in acetonitrile for 5 days, filtered, and vacuum-dried at 120 °C for 24 h. The activation of these two frameworks was confirmed by FT-IR spectroscopy, elemental analysis, and powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) analysis (Figures S4 and S5). The water stability of these two frameworks was also examined by soaking activated samples in water for 24 h. The PXRD patterns of water-treated samples confirmed that these two MOFs are stable in water (Figure S5).

decomposition temperature.type: gradual removal of coordinated water molecules

Connolly surfaces of (b) TMU-6 and (e) TMU-21, along the pore channels, with a probe radius of 1.2 Å, with the three interpenetrating frameworks colored red, blue, and orange. Representation of (c) TMU-6 and (f) TMU-21, showing the arrangement of L1 and L2 pillar ligands inside the honeycomb channel walls of TMU-6 and TMU-21, respectively. The benzene and naphthalene cores of L1 and L2 are shown as space-filling models.

metadata.title:
Effects of Extending the π‑Electron System
of Pillaring Linkers on Fluorescence Sensing of Aromatic Compounds
in Two Isoreticular Metal–Organic Frameworks
